review.title: A Rigorously Bayesian Beam Model and an Adaptive Full Scan Model for Range Finders in Dynamic Environments
review.abstract: This paper proposes and experimentally validates a Bayesian network model of a range finder adapted to dynamic environments. All modeling assumptions are rigorously explained, and all model parameters have a physical interpretation. This approach results in a transparent and intuitive model. With respect to the state of the art beam model this paper: (i) proposes a different functional form for the probability of range measurements caused by unmodeled objects, (ii) intuitively explains the discontinuity encountered in te state of the art beam model, and (iii) reduces the number of model parameters, while maintaining the same representational power for experimental data. The proposed beam model is called RBBM, short for Rigorously Bayesian Beam Model. A maximum likelihood and a variational Bayesian estimator (both based on expectation-maximization) are proposed to learn the model parameters.

sections.text: In addition, the RBBM is expanded to a full scan model in two steps: first to a full scan model for static environments and then to a full scan model for general, dynamic environments. The full scan model takes into account the dependence between beams and adapts to local sample density when using a particle filter. Unlike Gaussian-based state-of-the-art models, the proposed full scan model uses a sample-based approximation. This sample-based approximation enables the handling of dynamic environments and the acquisition of multimodality that occurs even in simple static environments.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In a probabilistic approach, inaccuracies are embedded in the stochastic nature of the model, that is, in the conditional probability density that represents the measurement process. It is critical that all kinds of inaccuracies that affect the measurements are embedded in the probabilistic sensor model. Inaccuracies result from sensor limitations, noise, and the fact that most complex environments can only be represented and perceived in a limited way. However, the dynamic nature of the environment in particular is an important source of inaccuracies. This dynamic nature results from the presence of unmodeled and possibly moving objects and people. This paper proposes a probabilistic range of sensor models for dynamic environments. sections.heading: 3.7 Validation
sections.text: The objective of this section is to demonstrate by means of a Monte Carlo simulation2 that the RBBM, Gb. (45), corresponds to the Bayesian network. A Monte Carlo simulation is an approximate inference method for Bayesian networks. The idea behind the Monte Carlo simulation is to draw random configurations of the network variables Z, X, M, N, XN = {XNj} j = 1: n, K, XK = {XKi} i = 1: k and Z-occl and to do so a sufficient number of times. Random configurations are selected by scanning the ancestors (Bishop, 2006), i.e. by successive sampling2. A Monte Carlo simulation is also referred to in Bayesian network literature as stochastic simulation (Jensen & Nielsen, 2007).

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: The objective of this section is threefold: (i) learning the model parameters (Eq. (48)) of the RBBM (Eq. (45)) based on experimental data; (ii) comparing the results of the proposed ML-EM and VB-EM estimator (Section 4); and (iii) comparing the results of the proposed estimators with the learning approach of the model proposed by Thrun (2005). To this end, two experimental setups from different fields of application in robotics will be used; the data for the first learning experiment will be collected during a typical mobile robot application in which the robot is equipped with a laser scanner and travels in an office environment; the data for the second learning experiment will be collected during a typical industrial pickand place operation in a human-populated environment; a laser scanner will be mounted on the industrial robot to make people and other unexpected objects aware in the workspace.

sections.heading: 5.1 First Learning Experiment
sections.text: In a first learning experiment, the experimental data collected by Thrun et al. (2005) are used, which consists of two series of measurements performed with a mobile robot traveling through a typical office environment. 10,000 measurements are selected from the series, centered around two different expected ranges. The two obtained series of measurements with different expected ranges are shown in Figure 11. The parameters of the learning algorithms are shown in Table 1. Figure 12 and Table 2 show the results of the ML-EM and VB-EM estimators for the RBBM compared to the results of the ML-EM estimator for the Thrun model (Thrun et al., 2005) for these two groups. The results are obtained by executing the learning algorithms for 30 iteration steps. sections.heading: 5.2 Second Learning Experiment
sections.text: The data for the second learning experiment is collected during a typical industrial pick-and-place operation in a human-populated environment. A Sick LMS 200 laser scanner is mounted on the first axis of an industrial Kuka 361 robot (Fig. 13). The laser scanner provides measurements of the robot environment and thus of humans and other unexpected objects in the robot's working area. Processing these measurements is a first step to make industrial robots aware of their potentially changing environment and as such move these robots out of their caves. In a first step, a map (Fig. 14) is created of the robot's static environment, i.e. without any unexpected objects or people moving by the robot rotating the first axis of the industrial object. Next, the robot performs a pick-and-place operation while a number of people randomly walk around the robot environment (Fig. 2).

sections.heading: 6.2 Sample-based Adaptive Full Scan Model for Dynamic Environments
sections.text: The adaptive beam model proposed by Pfaff et al. (2006) is suitable for use in dynamic environments because it uses the four-component mixed beam model (Thrun et al., 2005; Choset et et al., 2005). However, so far, the full-scan adaptive probability models developed by Pfaff et al. (2007) and Plagemann et al. (2007) have not been adapted for dynamic environments. However, the assumption that the beams are jointly Gaussian distributions and cannot capture the non-Gaussian uncertainty due to environmental dynamics prevents simple expansion to dynamic environments. In contrast, the sample-based approximation of the full scan be extended to environmental dynamics as proposed in Section 6.1. Fig. 18 (c) shows a probability map of the full-scan adaptive model (sample-based approximation) suitable for dynamic environments in the sample environment of Fig. 16. The probability map records P (z | x, m) as a function of the position on the map and shows that the marginalization over the environment U (x) of a sample in Equation (105) introduces not only a dependence between the beams but also multimodality.

sections.heading: 7. Discussion
sections.text: This work proposed and experimentally validated the RBBM, a strictly Bayesian network model of a range finder adapted to dynamic environments. All modeling assumptions are strictly explained, and all model parameters have a physical interpretation. This approach resulted in a transparent and intuitive model. Rigorous modeling revealed all the underlying assumptions and parameters. In this way, a clear physical interpretation of all parameters is achieved, which provides intuition for the parameter selection. In contrast to the model by Thrun et al. (2005), the assumption underlying the non-physical discontinuity in the RBBM is discovered. Furthermore, the paper suggests a different functional form for the probability of measurements caused by unmodeled objects Poccl (z | x, m) (equivalent. (1999) show that such approaches are only capable to model such noise on average, and, while these approaches work reliably with occasional sensor blockage, they are inadequate in situations where more than fifty percent of the measurements are corrupted. To handle measurement corruption more effectively, an approach based on outlier detection can be used. This approach uses an adapted sensor model, as explained in the previous paragraph. The idea is to investigate the cause of a sensor measurement and to reject measurements that are likely to be affected by unmodeled environment dynamics. metadata.abstractText: This paper proposes and experimentally validates a Bayesian network model of a range finder adapted to dynamic environments. All modeling assumptions are rigorously explained, and all model parameters have a physical interpretation. This approach results in a transparent and intuitive model. With respect to the state of the art beam model this paper: (i) proposes a different functional form for the probability of range measurements caused by unmodeled objects, (ii) intuitively explains the discontinuity encountered in the state of the art beam model, and (iii) reduces the number of model parameters, while maintaining the same representational power for experimental data. The proposed beam model is called RBBM, short for Rigorously Bayesian Beam Model. A maximum likelihood and a variational Bayesian estimator (both based on expectation-maximization) are proposed to learn the model parameters. Furthermore, the RBBM is extended to a full scan model in two steps: first, to a full scan model for static environments and next, to a full scan model for general, dynamic environments. The full scan model accounts for the dependency between beams and adapts to the local sample density when using a particle filter. In contrast to Gaussian-based state of the art models, the proposed full scan model uses a sample-based approximation. This sample-based approximation enables handling dynamic environments and capturing multimodality, which occurs even in simple static environments.
